title: Alexandru Nicolau
text:
Alexandru Nicolau (; January 1889 – September 27, 1937) was a <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n lawyer, <a href="socialism">socialist</a> and later <a href="communism">communist</a> activist. Active in the Romanian and <a href="France">French</a> socialist movements before and during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, he left for <a href="Russia">Russia</a> during the <a href="Russian%20Revolution">1917 Revolutions</a>. There, he became one of the organisers of Romanian <a href="Military%20volunteer">volunteer</a> detachments in support of the <a href="Soviet%20%28council%29%23Russian%20Revolution%20of%201917">Soviets</a>. Arrested shortly after returning to Romania in 1920, he left for <a href="Soviet%20Russia">Soviet Russia</a> after a successful prison escape. During the later part of his life he held teaching positions at several Soviet universities, before falling victim to the <a href="Great%20Purge">Great Purge</a> in 1937. His name was posthumously <a href="Rehabilitation%20%28Soviet%29">rehabilitated</a> both in the Soviet Union and in his native Romania.
Biography.
Early life and activity.
Nicolau was born in <a href="Bucharest">Bucharest</a> in 1889. As a student at the <a href="Saint%20Sava%20National%20College">Saint Sava High School</a>, he befriended <a href="Constantin%20Titel%20Petrescu">Constantin Titel Petrescu</a> and <a href="Mihail%20Cruceanu">Mihail Cruceanu</a>, both of whom would later become known as socialist militants. After finishing his secondary education, Nicolau trained as a lawyer, receiving a degree from the local <a href="University%20of%20Bucharest">University</a>, a <a href="PhD">PhD</a> in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, before being admitted to the <a href="Bucharest%20Bar">Bucharest Bar</a>. His first contacts with the Romanian socialist movement, still in disarray during that period, came through his membership in the Bucharest's Study Circle of the Socialist Students between 1908 and 1909. Soon after he began writing for "<a href="Rom%C3%A2nia%20Muncitoare">România Muncitoare</a>", the main socialist press venue. One of his first notable contributions was his correspondence from <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, criticising the <a href="Reformism">reformist</a> stance of the local socialist party. In 1911, "România Muncitoare" published Nicolau's <a href="Antimilitarism">anti-militarist</a> manifesto "To the recruits". Recalling the army's contribution in suppressing the <a href="1907%20Romanian%20Peasants%27%20Revolt">1907 Peasants' revolt</a>, the brochure called on the new <a href="Army%20recruit">recruits</a> to choose a different path and refuse to support the government crackdown on the demands of the workers and the peasant. As a result, in May 1912 he was put under trial before the Court of the <a href="Ilfov%20County">Ilfov County</a>, where he reaffirmed the ideas expressed in the manifesto. Defended by fellow socialists <a href="Mihail%20Gh.%20Bujor">Mihail Gh. Bujor</a>, <a href="Toma%20Dragu">Toma Dragu</a> and Titel Petrescu, and by socialist sympathizer <a href="Constantin%20Mille">Constantin Mille</a>, Nicolau was eventually acquitted by the jury. In June 1912, along with <a href="Constantin%20Dobrogeanu%20Gherea">Constantin Dobrogeanu Gherea</a>, <a href="Ecaterina%20Arbore">Ecaterina Arbore</a> and others, he represented the Bucharest Socialist Club at the Fifth Congress of the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Romania%20%281910%E2%80%931918%29">Social Democratic Party of Romania</a> (PSDR), being elected a member in the committee of the <a href="Cercul%20de%20Editur%C4%83%20Socialist%C4%83">party's publishing house</a>. In order to escape harassment from the authorities, Nicolau chose to leave Romania for Paris, where he continued his law studies at the <a href="University%20of%20Paris">Sorbonne</a>, and joined the <a href="French%20Section%20of%20the%20Workers%27%20International">French Section of the Workers' International</a>.
World War I and Russian Revolution.
In 1916, Romania joined <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> on the side of the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20I">Entente</a> and imposed an immediate ban on the local socialist movement, which had adopted a militant <a href="pacifism">pacifist</a> stance. Nicolau reacted by publishing in Paris a study highly critical of the Romanian ruling classes, titled "The Crime of the Romanian Oligarchy". Returning to Romania later in the war, he was kept under constant surveillance by <a href="Siguran%C8%9Ba">Siguranța</a>, the secret police. Nicolau was present in Iaşi during the revolutionary agitation which emerged during the 1917 <a href="May%20Day">May Day</a> celebrations and under the impression of the <a href="February%20Revolution">February Revolution</a>. Along the other social-democrats, he supported the position of the PSD leader <a href="Christian%20Rakovsky">Christian Rakovsky</a>, who believed the situation in Romania was not ripe for the overthrow of the monarchy.
Joining <a href="Christian%20Rakovsky">Christian Rakovsky</a> and Bujor, Nicolau left in June 1917 for Russia, where he entered the <a href="Russian%20Social%20Democratic%20Labour%20Party%20%28bolsheviks%29">Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (bolsheviks)</a>. He settled in <a href="Odessa">Odessa</a> and, along with Bujor, <a href="Ion%20Dic%20Dicescu">Ion Dic Dicescu</a>, and <a href="Alter%20Zalic">Alter Zalic</a>, he was one of the organisers and afterwards leaders of the "Romanian Committee for Social-Democratic Action" established in the city. Nicolau also became the editor of "Lupta" ("The Struggle"), which presented itself as the successor of "România Muncitoare" (renamed in 1914 to "Lupta zilnică", "The Daily Struggle"). After the <a href="October%20Revolution">October Revolution</a>, the Romanian socialists in Odessa saluted the new developments. Becoming increasingly communist in outlook, they also began agitating for a revolution in their home country. Such views were publicly expressed by Nicolau during his speech at the 2nd Congress of <a href="Rumcherod">Rumcherod</a>. In order to help the Soviets secure power in Southern Russia, on December 28, 1917, the Committee established the "Romanian Revolutionary Military Committee", which counted Nicolau, Bujor, and Dicescu among its leaders. The Revolutionary Committee worked in close cooperation with the Rumcherod, which provided it with material support. During the following period, two Romanian volunteer battalions were established by recruiting Romanian soldiers in <a href="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> and the Russian <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> ports, as well as workers who had been evacuated to Southern Russia. Between January and March 1918, the volunteers participated along the local <a href="Red%20Guards%20%28Russia%29">Red Guards</a> in battles against the troops of the <a href="Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a>, the regular Romanian Army which had occupied Bessarabia, as well as against the <a href="Central%20Powers">Central Powers</a> armies advancing from the Northwest.
The occupation of Odessa by <a href="Austro-Hungary">Austro</a>-<a href="German%20Empire">German</a> troops in the aftermath of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> forced the volunteer battalions to retreat to <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a> and central Russia, with the members of the Action Committee either going underground or leaving for Russian areas still under Soviet control. In August 1918, Nicolau, Dicescu and the other former members of the Action Committee which had reached <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a> created the "Romanian Communist Revolutionary Committee". The new committee, proclaimed the official representative of the PSDR in Russia, established contacts with the socialists in Bucharest and initiated an outreach campaign amongst the Romanian POWs in Russia. In late 1918, the Committee joined another Romanian group, the <a href="Agrarian%20socialism">radical agrarian</a> "<a href="Romanian%20Revolutionary%20Peasants%27%20Party">Romanian Revolutionary Peasants' Party</a>", to form an unified "Romanian Communist group" of the <a href="Russian%20Communist%20Party%20%28bolsheviks%29">Russian Communist Party (bolsheviks)</a>. Nicolau was elected the group's chairman, with another PSDR member, Ion Penţa, being elected secretary and representative to the <a href="Federation%20of%20Foreign%20Groups">Federation of Foreign Groups</a>. Nicolau also began publishing regularly in "Foaia țăranului", the former organ of the Revolutionary Peasants' Party. In 1919 the Publishing House of the Romanian Communist Groups in Soviet Russia published Nicolau's brochure "The Socialist Revolution in Romania". The pamphlet acknowledged the Bolshevik support for the Romanian communists, and called on Romanians to follow the revolutionary path taken by the Russian communists under the leadership of <a href="Lenin">Lenin</a>. During August 1919, as the Soviets regained Odessa, Nicolau was one of the editors of the short-lived newspaper "<a href="Sc%C3%AEnteia">Scânteea</a>".
Later life and death.
Alexandru Nicolau returned to Romania in 1920, however he was soon apprehended by the authorities, and imprisoned in <a href="Jilava">Jilava</a> along with a larger group of communists, including <a href="Alecu%20Constantinescu">Alecu Constantinescu</a>. The group made a successful bid for escape on the night of December 2, 1920, and, following a short stay in <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, most escapees made their way to <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>. On March 31, 1931, Nicolau was <a href="Trial%20in%20absentia">sentenced in absentia</a> to death by the Romanian authorities. In <a href="Soviet%20Russia">Soviet Russia</a>, he joined the local group of Romanian communists, and participated as a non-voting delegate in the <a href="Comintern%23Third%20World%20Congress">Third World Congress</a> of the <a href="Communist%20International">Communist International</a>, held in Moscow in June 1921. Nicolau also joined the Romanian section of the <a href="Communist%20University%20of%20the%20National%20Minorities%20of%20the%20West">Communist University of the National Minorities of the West</a>, where he lectured on topics such as history and social sciences, and worked as a teacher for the <a href="Moscow%20State%20Linguistic%20University">Moscow Institute of Foreign Languages</a>.
Nicolau was among the Romanian Communist refugees in Soviet Russia who in 1924 signed a memorandum calling for the creation of a <a href="Moldovans">Moldovan</a> national territory inside the <a href="Ukrainian%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, near the disputed border with Romania. Along with Dicescu, the main author of the document, Nicolau considered Moldovans to be <a href="Romanians">Romanians</a>, and saw the new polity primarily as a base for propaganda across the <a href="Dniester">Dniester</a>, in Bessarabia and Romania. Such views were however rejected by the Bessarabian Communists who, after gaining the support of the Ukrainian leadership, enforced a cultural policy emphasizing the distinctiveness of Moldovan identity in the newly created <a href="Moldovan%20Autonomous%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Moldovan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic</a>.
Arrested on August 14, 1937, during the <a href="Stalinist%20purges">Stalinist purges</a>, Nicolau was sentenced to death on September 27, 1937, by the <a href="Military%20Collegium%20of%20the%20Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20USSR">Military Collegium of the Supreme Court of the USSR</a> on fabricated charges of "espionage and involvement in counter-revolutionary terrorist organisations". He was executed on the same day, and buried in the <a href="Donskoy%20Cemetery">Donskoy Cemetery</a> in Moscow.
He was posthumously rehabilitated on September 15, 1956, through a decision of the Soviet Supreme Court during the <a href="De-Stalinization">De-Stalinisation</a> campaign. In a symbolic gesture, his name was also rehabilitated in Romania during the April 1968 Plenary Session of the Central Committee of the <a href="Romanian%20Communist%20Party">Romanian Communist Party</a>.
